newsitem.title: USA: Counsels seek limited probe of La. Senate race.
newsitem.headline: Counsels seek limited probe of La. Senate race.

text.p: Two outside counsels recommended Tuesday they be allowed to conduct a limited investigation of charges of fraudulent voting in last year's Senate race in Louisiana.
Democrat Mary Landrieu was declared winner of the Nov. 5 election by 5,788 votes, but her Republican challenger, Louis "Woody" Jenkins, claimed she won because of fraud.
Landrieu, the daughter of former New Orleans Mayor Moon Landrieu, was sworn in Jan. 7 without prejudice, meaning she could be removed from office if fraud is proven.

The counsels, Washington attorneys Robert Bauer, a Democrat, and William Canfield, III, a Republican, were hired by the Senate Rules Committee to determine if a full investigation of the charges by Jenkins was justified.

They recommended dismissing four of Jenkins' charges but said three others were serious enough to warrant a limited investigation. The committee of nine Republicans and seven Democrats is expected to vote next week on whether to accept their recommendations or take other action.
Jenkins, at a Washington news conference, said he was pleased by the report. "We welcome an investigation," he said, adding he hoped a new election would be ordered this year.
Landrieu scheduled a news conference for later in the afternoon.

In their report to the committee, the counsels said, "While counsel cannot conclude that the petitioner (Jenkins) has met the applicable burden at this stage in the process to justify a full investigation, they also cannot conclude that these claims are properly dismissed at this time."

They said they found "certain specific claims of fraud justify a limited investigation focused on the ... question of whether there is substantial competent evidence of fraud to indicate a probability that the election was wrongly certified, and that a full investigation is required."
"The claims subject to this investigation are: vote buying; multiple voting and registration and voting by ineligible persons," Bauer and Canfield said.
They recommended that claims by Jenkins of campaign finance and election law violations, mismatched voter signatures, election commissioner malfeasance and voter machine malfunction be dismissed.
"Counsel notes that the petitioner does not allege, and the evidence as submitted does not suggest, any involvement in these alleged fraudulent activities by (Landrieu) or her campaign," they said.

They said a limited investigation would involve interviews with key witnesses such as campaign aides and a review of documentation for the claims submitted by Jenkins. They said they did not think they would need much more time to finish their work but would need subpoena power.
Senate Democratic Leader Tom Daschle of South Dakota said he believed the report exonerated Landrieu and dismissed most of the allegations made by Jenkins.
